text: hi welcome to my cupcake addiction my
all-time favorite movie as a kid was the
Lion King so today we're going to be
making a Lion King inspired Safari cake
that's not just the berry on the outside
its Safari all the way through you're
going to need a ruler a serrated knife
and offset spatula and a small serrated
knife a fondant roller a scalpel or an
exacto knife a pair of scissors I've got
some corn flour in a shaker I've got
some nonstick cooking spray and I'm
using the vanilla cupcake recipe from
the cupcake addiction recipe book which
I'll link to down below I've got a
double batch of our straight vanilla
cake recipe I've got some extra bowls
and some food colors in the food colors
I've got black red yellow orange and
some bright white I've got some black
fondant and a few spares ziploc bags and
some cocoa and two spoons you can also
use brown food coloring in place of the
cocoa I've got some of that perfectly
pipeable buttercream frosting and I will
leave a link to that recipe in the
description box below but I've colored
mine orange red yellow and white I'm
using one of my recent baking fines the
Wilton easy layers tin sets so this is
basically a set of five six inch round
by about one inch high cake tins instead
of having to wait when you're making
rainbow cakes or layer cakes for each
individual layer to bake
you've got five short tins and you can
just bake them all together I'll leave a
link where you can find out more about
that tin set in the description box
below I've teamed up with a couple of my
fellow baking channels to bring you guys
a little assortment of recipes that you
can make using this tin set and I've
also got some of those tin sets to give
away so only details down below and how
you can enter the competition to win one
of those tin sets and each of the
channels in this collaboration has a set
to giveaway I'm presenting my cake on a
black cake board today but you can use
any color you like I've also got my
printable Safari animal template which I
will link to in the description box down
below I've got my trusty old craft mat
and I'm using that today just to make
sure that I don't scratch up my benches
as I'm cutting out my animals the first
layers we're making today are going to
be two of the cheetah or leopard print
so you want to take a couple of
tablespoons of your vanilla cake mix to
depending on how evil your Ziploc bags
are press it down and seal it up pop it
off to the side then I took three
tablespoons of that vanilla mix and put
it in two separate bowls one of those
bowls I'm adding a bit of cocoa too or
brown food coloring and you just want to
stir that through just to color it like
a light chocolate brown for the inside
of our leopard spots and the other one
you want to add some black food coloring
too you're going to need a little bit of
food coloring here because you do want
it to be nice and black scoop that Brown
and that black both in two separate
ziplock bags and seal them up prepare
your pans with a generous amount of your
cooking spray and then you just want to
take your scissors and cut quite a
generous size tip off the yellow cake
mix or the vanilla cake mix and then
fine a smaller tip of both the black and
the brown I'm going to pipe a really
thick stripe or a thick circle of that
vanilla cake mix in each of those pans
and I am using your vanilla or a yellow
cake mixer not a white put a very very
thin layer of cake in the bottom of the
pan and then level it out with a spoon
and then taking your black bag you want
to pipe a dot in the center of one of
your tins and then like a target around
it so a circle around it or a stripe of
black around it you want to repeat this
in both of your cake tins this is where
it starts to get a bit tricky you want
to take your brown cake mix now and
you're going to pipe the brown directly
on top of that black so on top of the
dot and then on top of each of the lines
not beside it the reason that I love
this particular cake recipe is because I
know that it's thick enough to hold its
own for this particular design once all
of your targets are piped take that
yellow cake and you're going to pipe it
in the spaces in between each of your
target circles you've really got to pipe
it in here because if you just tried to
spread it you'd collapse all of the
design that we've made so be a bit
careful and just try to keep as much of
that pattern sitting where it is as you
can you want to bring this cake mix all
the way up to the outer edges of your
cake tin because you need them to rise
and you need all of your layers to be
about the same size but they are quite
thin so you want as much cake as you can
get in your Safari cake
once you've piped all of that yellow
cake on I just went around and did kind
of like another half a circle or a half
a line at little random intervals this
is just to add a little bit more of that
cheetah
happening to the cake because you don't
want to have not enough but the top of
this is going to rise and get carved off
so don't be too fussy I just did the
black with the brown on top and I didn't
worry about the last layer of black to
cover that Brown once you're done you
can either stick them in the oven to
start cooking or you can set them to the
side and you can cook all of your cake
layers together but they're only going
to take about 10 to 15 minutes for a
zebra now we're only going to do one
zebra and that's going to be the center
layer of my safari cake so I'm adding
some of that bright white food coloring
now that my mix is nice and white as is
there should be I'm scooping it into a
ziploc bag and then you want to cut
another generous sized corner off so it
should be quite a fat tip grease your
next pan with that cooking spray and for
this one you're going to pipe the same
sort of a fat sausage of that white cake
mix around the outer edge you want to
give that sort of a double layer because
you do want to build up those edges a
little bit and then you can take that
wire and you want to pipe a really big
blob of that cake mix in the middle
taking your black now you want to insert
another blob and I'm actually going to
shove the bag right inside the white and
sort of let the black spill out a little
bit and then I'm going to pop the white
inside the black so you'll see it's kind
of like bulging that mix out because
this particular design is better suited
to a thinner or more liquid cake mix you
want to take your pan and just give it a
couple of good taps on the bench then
you want to keep going with your design
so once again another blob of the white
and then another blob of the black it's
a catch-22 because you do need that sick
firm cake to make that cheetah print
work but really for the zebra and the
tiger a thinner more liquid cake is
better you don't necessarily want to
have to go and make two or three
separate batches here so this is how we
work with a thicker cake mix to get that
zebra tiger design you'll see I'm just
squirting in and just tapping down until
that black line reaches all the way to
the outer edge and you want to make sure
again that your cake mix comes right up
to the rim of your cake tin make sure
that you've got at least a full ziplock
bag full of your black cake mix and then
check the rest of your brown and your
white into that vanilla cake mix with a
generous amount of orange food coloring
mix it all the way through and you'll
have sort of like not a bright orange
but like a brownie orange scoop that
into your last ziplock bag and then cut
off another quite fat generous tip don't
forget to
raise your trays again but it's exactly
the same as our zebra print so those two
fat circles around the outside and then
a big blob of orange in the center
followed by black and orange and black
and a few taps your two Tiger layers are
ready to go into the oven and you'll
know they're all cooked when they spring
back when touched in the middle while
those are baking and cooling you can
roll out your fondant don't roll it too
thick here you want it nice and thin and
then using your scalpel or your exacto
knife you just want to sort of separate
the amount that you need because it will
dry out carefully trace around whatever
shape you're doing I'm using the
rhinoceros and I've pre-cut out the rest
of those sheets and I'll also mention
that when I printed them I printed them
on a relatively thick cardstock just so
they're a bit sturdier for me to hold in
place as I'm cutting I sort of cut out
the base shape of my animal and then I
went in with a little scalpel and just
really find out the details so that I
wasn't pulling the fondant and so that
I've got a really nice shape and then
using my fingers I just neaten up around
the edges so there were no kind of rough
edges store those in between a folded
over piece of plastic wrap so that they
don't dry out and you can make them a
couple of hours in advance and set them
off to the side until you're ready to
use them with all of your layers now
baked and completely cool it's time to
carve them up when you call these I
should mention you want to flip them
over so that they're resting on the top
of the cake on the cooling rack which is
actually going to help to compact the
cake down and make it flatter on top so
you're not cutting away too much of your
design using your large bread knife just
trim off as little as you can get away
with to make those tops as nice and
level as possible and cutting away as
much of that crispy golden edge as you
can turn them over upside down and you
want to cut any gold and crispy edges
off the bottom you want to do this with
layer cakes because you don't really
want to see any of that kind of yellow
crispy baked edge you only want to see
that beautiful print and the frosting
that we're going to put in using my
smaller serrated edge knife I'm just
going around the outer edge cutting off
any crunchy edges and you should be left
with a relatively clean patterned layer
repeat this with all five of your layers
and then we'll be ready to start
stacking and decorating I've got all my
trimmed layers laid out so you want to
take a nice little smear of buttercream
and just pop it down on the board as
something to glue your cake to and I'm
starting with one of the tiger layers or
the bottom so with his layers they're
going to be quite crumbly and they've
all been a lot of black coloring and
other colors in them so do a really fine
crumb coat and really press that into
the cake to capture all the crumbs wipe
your scraper off before adding just
another couple of millimeters of
buttercream you don't want too much
frosting in between your layers but this
will just helped get your main layer of
frosting nice and clean now I'm going to
take one of my leopard print layers and
pop that on top adding yet another crumb
coat before adding my actual layer of
frosting after that leopard comes a
zebra and then we're going to add the
other leopard and the tiger on top to
kind of even out the positioning of all
of our different prints once your cakes
all stacked and your Tigers on top you
want to give it a crumb coat with that
orange frosting so you can see I'm using
my offset spatula I'm really working
that frosting back and forward so it's
going into all the creases and capturing
all the crumbs as well as on top so this
is just a really thin layer pop that off
into the freezer for about 30 minutes
and let that crumb coat set once it's
set you want to start at the bottom with
your yellow frosting for sort of the
bottom of our Savannah skyline and I'm
just putting it on the bottom edge of my
spatula before applying a generous
amount of it to the base of the cake
smooth that yellow off as best as you
can and then you want to add a bit of
the orange in the middle making sure
that it's slightly overlapping the
yellow layer at the bottom taking your
red you want to smooth that onto the top
of your cake and then just with a tiny
bit on the end of the spatula so you
don't get too much just put it along the
top inch or so of the cake you want to
have the least red of all of the colors
once you've got that red you want to use
your offset spatula and I'm wiping it in
between each of my scrapes but I'm
basically just applying a bit of
pressure and I'm smoothing those two
colored frostings together once you
smooth the orange and the red together
you'll see they start to blend into each
other once you've done the orange and
the red together move the spatula down
the cake and start doing the yellow and
the orange together so you can see what
we're getting there it's almost like a
little watercolor effect or a really
nice painted effect of that African
skyline I'm going to take a ruler now
this is my cake decorating ruler so
whatever one you use make sure it's
clean and dry but I'm just going to
scrape a very
a light layer off the outside of that
cake to get it as smooth and as neat as
I can be careful that you don't scrape
too much and actually hit the cake
underneath to even off the top I'm using
the offset spatula and you'll see that
I'm just lightly dragging the edges of
my cake back into the center so it just
really evens them up and gives you a bit
of a sharp edge you can finish your cake
off by taking your pre-cut out fondant
animals and just sticking them straight
to that buttercream don't take too long
because buttercream frosting does start
to crust after about 10 to 15 minutes so
once you've smoothed it out get your
animals and your trees on there as quick
as you can if you're a bit time-poor the
outside decoration for this cake is so
incredibly simple you could just do this
on a straight 6-inch chocolate cake or a
vanilla cake for a really cute really
fast and really easy lion king themed
Safari cake I hope you guys have enjoyed
my take on a lion king themed cake this
was such a lot of fun to make and when
we cut into it check out those layers
inside there's so much going on they are
absolutely amazing this cake is a
showstopper make sure that you check out
those other channels I will link to the
playlist down below as always thanks
very much for tuning in to my cupcake
addiction
